abstract.p: Steven A King letter contends that concussions, not steroids, may have caused depression that former football player Andre Waters struggled with before committing suicide (S)

block.p: Re ''Expert Ties Ex-Player's Suicide to Brain Damage From Football,'' Jan 18:

Obviously, no one can know for certain why Andre Waters ended his life. But there are certainly other possible explanations for his depression. A majority of retired football players suffer from chronic pain as a result of injuries, and many people with this problem are depressed and even suicidal.
Re ''Expert Ties Ex-Player's Suicide to Brain Damage From Football,'' Jan 18:

Obviously, no one can know for certain why Andre Waters ended his life. But there are certainly other possible explanations for his depression. A majority of retired football players suffer from chronic pain as a result of injuries, and many people with this problem are depressed and even suicidal.
Most retired players fade into obscurity, a potentially difficult journey for someone who has been the center of attention and received the adulation of millions.
Steven A. King, M.D. New York

Now that the invaluable work of Chris Nowinski and Dr. Bennet Omalu has made football fans aware of the damage players can suffer, I hope they will never again confuse the seemingly choreographed ballet of television with the helmet-crushing, neuron-damaging mayhem that takes place on the field.
After reading this article, I have lost my taste for football.
